001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * An interface for "point hashes", that is, functions that produce usually-unique integer results given multiple
005 * integer inputs. The hash functions this guarantees an implementor will provide all take int inputs and return an int.
006 * There are lots of cases where an implementor would have other functions that take long inputs or return longs, and in
007 * those cases the interface methods would probably be implemented by delegating to the long inputs and/or casting the
008 * result to a long. Implementors must have a {@link #setState(int)} function, but it doesn't have to do anything if the
009 * algorithm doesn't support a state; similarly, {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)} can return the same thing as
010 * {@link #hash(int, int)} if states aren't supported. If states are supported, then calling {@link #hash(int, int)}
011 * while the state is, for example, 42 should be the same as calling {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)} with a state
012 * parameter of 42 (regardless of what the state actually is in the implementor).
013 * <br>
014 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 4/13/2020.
015 */
016public interface IPointHash {
017    void setState(int state);
018    int hash(int x, int y);
019    int hash(int x, int y, int z);
020    int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w);
021    int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u);
022    int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v);
023    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state);
024    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state);
025    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state);
026    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state);
027    int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state);
028
029    /**
030     * A convenience abstract class to implement IPointHash when you have an int for state. Subclasses will need to
031     * implement {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)},  {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int)},
032     * {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int)}, and  {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int, int, int)}.
033     * They can optionally override {@link #setState(int)}, and can at their discretion provide an accessor for the
034     * protected int {@link #state}.
035     */
036    abstract class IntImpl implements IPointHash {
037        protected int state = 42;
038        public IntImpl(){
039            setState(42);
040        }
041        public IntImpl(int state){
042            setState(state);
043        }
044
045        @Override
046        public void setState(int state) {
047            this.state = state;
048        }
049
050        @Override
051        public int hash(int x, int y) {
052            return hashWithState(x, y, state);
053        }
054
055        @Override
056        public int hash(int x, int y, int z) {
057            return hashWithState(x, y, z, state);
058        }
059
060        @Override
061        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w) {
062            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, state);
063        }
064
065        @Override
066        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u) {
067            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, state);
068        }
069
070        @Override
071        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v) {
072            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
073        }
074    }
075    /**
076     * A convenience abstract class to implement IPointHash when you have a long for state. Subclasses will need to
077     * implement {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int)},  {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int)},
078     * {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int)}, {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int, int)}, an
079     * {@link #hashWithState(int, int, int, int, int, int, int)}.
080     * They can optionally override {@link #setState(int)} or {@link #setState(long)}, and can at their discretion
081     * provide an accessor for the protected long {@link #state}.
082     */
083    abstract class LongImpl implements IPointHash {
084        protected long state = 42;
085        public LongImpl(){
086            setState(42);
087        }
088        public LongImpl(int state){
089            setState(state);
090        }
091        public LongImpl(long state){
092            setState(state);
093        }
094
095        @Override
096        public void setState(int state) {
097            this.state = state;
098        }
099        
100        public void setState(long state){
101            this.state = state;
102        }
103
104        @Override
105        public int hash(int x, int y) {
106            return hashWithState(x, y, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
107        }
108
109        @Override
110        public int hash(int x, int y, int z) {
111            return hashWithState(x, y, z, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
112        }
113
114        @Override
115        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w) {
116            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
117        }
118
119        @Override
120        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u) {
121            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
122        }
123        @Override
124        public int hash(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v) {
125            return hashWithState(x, y, z, w, u, v, (int) (state ^ state >>> 32));
126        }
127    }
128}
